column22:
Jowar is primarily a Kharif crop, with sowing done during the onset of monsoon (last week of May to mid-July). However, rabi cultivation of jowar is feasible under assured irrigation, using early-maturing grain sorghum varieties such as CSV‑216R, CSV‑18R, CSV‑22, which are part of the national rabi package. In Haryana specifically, according to ICAR‑CRIDA contingency planning, the sowing window for rabi‑rainfed sorghum is end of September to 20 October, while for rabi‑irrigated cultivation it ranges from end of October to 15 November.
Therefore:
- Kharif jowar (North India/Haryana): Optimal sowing time- late May to mid-July.
- Rabi jowar under irrigation: Under irrigation, sowing may extend from late September up to mid-November, depending on water availability and cropping schedule.

column15:

It primarily develops and spreads under the warm and humid weather conditions common in regions like Fatehabad, Haryana. Effective management requires a combination of preventive and control measures. Preventive Measures (Before and During Sowing) Proactive steps are crucial to minimize the risk of infection. Always use certified, disease-free seeds as the first line of defense. Before sowing, treat seeds with Carbendazim 12% + Mancozeb 63% WP at a rate of 2 g per kg of seeds. Ensure proper field drainage to avoid water stagnation, as excess moisture promotes fungal growth. If you notice symptoms on the leaves, take immediate action to control the spread. Remove and destroy infected leaves and plant debris to reduce the source of fungal spores in the field. You can also do soil solarization as an additional measure to reduce soil-borne pathogens before planting. If the disease is spreading, apply one of the following fungicides, ensuring thorough coverage by using approximately 200 liters of water per acre: Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600-800 g/acre, Chlorothalonil 75% WP @ 500 g/acre, Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% SC @ 200 ml/acre. Use a high volume of water, typically 200-250 liters per acre, to ensure the spray reaches all parts of the plant, especially the underside of the leaves. To prevent resistance, do not use the same chemical class repeatedly. Apply the spray in the early morning or late afternoon when temperatures are lower and the wind is calm.

नमस्ते किसान भाइयों, आज हम बात करेंगे कपास की फसल में लगने वाले पत्तियों का धब्बा रोग, जिसे अल्टरनेरिया लीफ स्पॉट भी कहा जाता है। यह एक फ़फ़ूंदजनित रोग है, जो गर्म और नमी वाले मौसम में तेजी से फैलता है।

इस रोग में पत्तियों पर भूरे-काले गोल धब्बे बनते हैं। धीरे-धीरे पत्तियाँ सूखने लगती हैं और पौधे कमजोर हो जाते हैं, जिससे पैदावार घट जाती है।

बुआई से पहले और खेती के दौरान क्या सावधानियाँ रखें?
हमेशा प्रमाणित और रोगमुक्त बीज प्रयोग करें।
बीज को बुआई से पहले कार्बेन्डाज़िम 12% + मैंकोजेब 63% WP से 2 ग्राम प्रति किलो बीज की दर से उपचारित करें।
खेत में पानी रुकने न दें, नाली व्यवस्था सही रखें।
फसल चक्र अपनाएँ और खेत साफ रखें।

अगर फसल में रोग दिख जाए तो क्या करें?
संक्रमित पत्तियाँ और अवशेष खेत से निकालकर नष्ट करें।
रोग फैलने पर इनमें से किसी एक दवा का छिड़काव करें (200–250 लीटर पानी प्रति एकड़):
मैंकोजेब 75% WP @ 600–800 ग्राम
क्लोरोथालोनिल 75% WP @ 500 ग्राम
एजो़क्सीस्ट्रोबिन 11% + टेब्यूकोनाज़ोल 18.3% SC @ 200 मिली
छिड़काव सुबह या शाम को करें, जब तापमान कम हो और हवा शांत हो। बार-बार एक ही दवा का प्रयोग न करें।

किसान भाइयों, सही समय पर रोकथाम और छिड़काव से आप अपनी कपास की फसल को पत्तियों के धब्बा (अल्टरनेरिया लीफ स्पॉट) रोग से बचाकर अच्छी पैदावार ले सकते हैं।

तेज़ प्रकोप होने पर चयनित कीटनाशकों का प्रयोग करें (200 लीटर पानी प्रति एकड़):
इमामेक्टिन बेंजोएट 5 SG @ 80 ग्राम/एकड़
स्पिनोसैड 45 SC @ 75–100 मिली/एकड़
क्लोरेंट्रानिलीप्रोल 18.5 SC @ 60 मिली/एकड़
छिड़काव हमेशा शाम के समय करें, जब तापमान कम हो और असर ज़्यादा पड़े।
बार-बार एक ही दवा का प्रयोग न करें, अलग-अलग दवा समूहों को बदल-बदलकर प्रयोग करें ताकि कीट में प्रतिरोधक क्षमता न बने।
संक्रमित खोल (बॉल्स) खेत से हटा दें और फसल कटाई के बाद खेत की गहरी जुताई करें।

हर दवा की अपनी प्रि-हार्वेस्ट इंटरवल (PHI) अवधि होती है। यानी छिड़काव और तोड़ाई के बीच का समय। इसे ज़रूर ध्यान रखें:
इमामेक्टिन – 14 दिन
स्पिनोसैड – 7 दिन
क्लोरेंट्रानिलीप्रोल – 15 दिन
इससे फसल सुरक्षित रहेगी और तोड़ाई करने वाले मज़दूरों के लिए भी कोई हानि नहीं होगी।

तो किसान भाइयों, नियमित निगरानी और सही समय पर दवा के प्रयोग से आप कपास की फसल को सुंडी (अमेरिकन बॉलवर्म) से बचा सकते हैं और अच्छी पैदावार ले सकते हैं।

column25: Anthracnose and Scab are fungal diseases that cause dark, sunken spots on your bottle gourd fruits, making them unmarketable. To control both diseases effectively, you must rotate fungicides. For a preventive or early-stage spray, a contact + systemic combination like Azoxystrobin + Tebuconazole at 200 ml per acre is a modern and highly effective option. A crucial expert tip is to also remove and destroy any infected leaves and fruits to reduce the spread of the fungus in your field. Most importantly, after spraying, you must wait for at least 5-7 days (the Pre-Harvest Interval) before harvesting any fruit to ensure the vegetables are completely safe for consumption.

column27: Anthracnose is a common fungal disease in papaya that causes dark, sunken spots on the fruits. These spots later turn black and can spoil the fruit completely if not controlled on time. To manage this first try to use only disease-free and certified seeds or seedlings. Keeping proper spacing between plants is also important, as it helps in good air movement and prevents fungus from developing. Try to avoid overhead irrigation, using drip irrigation is better, as it keeps the leaves and fruits dry. Also, regularly check your plants and remove any infected leaves or fruits from the field to stop the disease from spreading. For natural prevention, you can spray bio-fungicides like Trichoderma viride or Pseudomonas fluorescens at 5–10 grams per litre of water. If the infection becomes serious, then you can spray Chlorothalonil 75 WP at 2 grams per litre or Tebuconazole 25.9 EC at 0.5 ml per litre of water. Do not spray any chemical pesticide 3 weeks before harvesting of papaya so that the pesticide residue breaks down and the fruits become safe for consumption.

column25: Aphids are small insects that suck plant juice, making wheat plants weak and yellow. They attack mostly in late crop stages (after flowering), especially when the weather is cool and dry. If not controlled in time, aphids can reduce grain size and final yield. To control aphids in wheat, spray Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 80 gram per acre or Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 100 ml per acre, mixed in 200 liters of water. These are easily available in Haryana and give good results. Spray when aphid numbers are seen on 8–10 plants out of 100 plants (that's mean it is ETL - Economic Threshold Level of aphids in wheat), at this time you have to take action immediately. For better results, spray in the morning or evening when wind is low. As an alternative, also you can use  Flonicamid 50% WG @ 60 gram per acre in 200 litres of water  for good control and better resistance. As a safer option and for bio control, you can also use Neem-based insecticide (Azadirachtin 1500 ppm) @ 300–400 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Rotate chemicals every season to avoid resistance. Keep the field clean after harvest to reduce future pest attack. Always read the label before spraying and wear protective clothes.

column27: Gulli Danda (Phalaris minor) is a major weed in wheat fields that looks similar to wheat and grows rapidly, making it hard to identify early. It competes for nutrients, water, and sunlight, leading to significant yield loss if not controlled in time. The best control method is timely application of post-emergence herbicide at the 2–4 leaf stage of the weed. Farmers should spray either Sulfosulfuron 75 WG at 13 grams per acre or  Pinoxaden 5 EC at 400 ml per acre, mixed in 150 litres of water. Spraying should be done during clear weather, not in the evening or rainy conditions, and full field coverage is necessary for effective control. For better control Gulli Danda, avoid using the same chemical group repeatedly. Instead, rotate or alternate herbicides with different modes of action every year. Also, using resistant wheat varieties like PBW 343, HD 2967, or DBW 187 helps reduce infestation. Additionally, follow up with Tebuconazole or Triadimefon sprays in alternate years to manage resistance build-up in weeds and associated diseases. Timely and proper weed management not only saves yield but also improves grain quality.

column27: Cauliflower is generally not suited for the Zaid season (February to April) due to high temperatures, as it is a cole crop that requires a cool climate with an optimum temperature range of 15–20°C for proper curd formation. Therefore, there is no practical option to grow cauliflower during the Zaid season. Which are sown in May–June. Prepare nursery beds in partial shade and sow seeds in May–June. Transplant seedlings after 25–30 days, maintaining a spacing of 45 × 30 cm in the main field. Provide light, frequent irrigation during the nursery stage to prevent heat stress. Timely irrigation is also critical during vegetative growth and curd formation. Under good management practices, these early varieties can yield approximately 80–100 quintals per acre.
